title: UCU Rising: strike paused, campaign continues

last_post.content:
We have reached a point in discussions with our employers where we have made significant progress across a range of issues. To allow our ongoing negotiations to continue in a constructive environment we have agreed to pause action across both disputes for the next two weeks and create a period of calm.

This means the strikes on 21, 22, 23, 27, 28 February, and 1, 2 March will not go ahead. All the action scheduled after these dates remains in place.

title: How Brisbane Independent School prevented outbreaks of COVID-19, despite Omicron wave

last_post.content:
A small primary school in Brisbane's west has done what many others have been unable to achieve during COVID-19's Omicron wave in Queensland: remain outbreak-free.

They studied airflow patterns with a smoke machine, used an aranet4 to monitor CO2, and purchased air purifiers.

Much like the current migration from Twitter, organizers worked around technical and social constraints about where they talk and with whom, and how to moderate community conversations.

I had almost forgotten about the year where I made timelapses of the sunsets behind @SutroTower and automatically uploaded them: https://www.flickr.com/photos/missionsunsets/page6

One of the values of pre-Internet newspapers and magazines was serendipity. They showed us things we didn't know we cared about, helped us see more of our complex world, and occasionally made our jaws drop.

The Internet is full of serendipity. My feed here provides some, but I find more via newsletters. Here are two I enjoy when they arrive in my inbox:

From @mathewi https://newsletter.mathewingram.com/

From @davepell: https://nextdraft.com/

How do you get serendipity?

#introduction The Women Writers Project is excited to move to Mastodon!

The WWP was founded in 1988 at Brown University, and moved to Northeastern University in 2013. The core of our work involves richly encoded transcriptions of early women’s writing using the TEI Guidelines, and related publications and research initiatives on things like representing racialized identities in digital archives, using machine learning techniques on TEI-encoded data, teaching with digital collections, and exploring the social justice implications of markup strategies. We also maintain an extensive open-access curriculum on text encoding and related digital humanities tools (https://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/outreach/resources/index.html).

Please follow us here for announcements, updates, and work in progress. We also maintain a listserv (https://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/outreach/lists.html) for those who would like to participate in more detailed discussions of the WWP’s work, and we blog about our research at the WWP blog (https://wwp.northeastern.edu/blog/).
